docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Philip Strax, a radiologist whose early and passionate advocacy of the mammogram helped revolutionize breast-cancer detection, died on Tuesday at a daughter's home in Bethesda, Md. He was 90. A general practitioner with a small family practice in Manhattan, Dr. Strax was spurred into a single-minded battle against breast cancer in 1947, when his first wife died of the disease.

headline.main: Dr. Philip Strax, 90, Is Dead; An Advocate of Mammograms

docs.lead_paragraph: Song Pengfei passes his days in a spare 12-by- 12-foot room moving from the bed with the red-checked blanket, to the chair, to a donated computer. His parents, their lives crammed into the adjacent sitting room, spend their days worrying. Shy to begin with, the soft-spoken 17-year-old says his energy and spirits are just ''so-so.'' He fainted recently on a street nearby and lay on the ground until an elderly stranger rescued him.

headline.main: Health System In China Fails As AIDS Enters

docs.abstract: Small but growing number of Chinese are infected with HIV, virus that causes AIDS, in nation largely unprepared to deal with disease emotionally, financially and medically; estimated 300,000 people have virus in population of 1.3 billion and most are not sick; numbers are rising despite aggressive government education drive; AIDS specialists are rare and discrimination and ignorance widespread; map; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Internet security software maker Verisign Inc. said today that the United States agency that controls software exports would allow the company to ship its high-security products to a broader set of overseas customers. Verisign stock surged after news of the expanded United States export approval, rising $14.75, or 14 percent, to $119, in Nasdaq trading.

headline.main: U.S. Eases Up on Security Software Exports

docs.abstract: Internet security software maker Verisign Inc says that US Department of Commerce's Bureau of Export Administration will allow company to ship its high-security products to broader set of overseas customers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest auto maker, hired a consultant today to help plan medical treatments for 60,000 salaried workers and their dependents, an effort it says will make health care more consistent and control its $4.5 billion annual tab. Beginning April 1, the care-management company Health International Inc. will help to set treatment plans for white-collar workers covered by a traditional fee-for-service or preferred provider plan at G.M. or its parts unit, the Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten years ago I wrote a column that might have been called ''the myth of the negative mammogram.'' In it I discussed the fact that 10 percent to 15 percent of breast cancers do not show up on a mammogram and cautioned women that any suspicious area in the breast should be biopsied even when the mammogram is negative. Last month, I became living proof of the value of that advice. I'd been having annual mammograms for about 13 years with no evidence of anything wrong. Likewise at my exam this year, my radiologist for the last eight years, Dr. Doreen Liebeskind, delivered the news that my X-rays looked fine. However, this time I feared something was the matter.

headline.main: Living Proof: Mammograms Are Not Always Enough

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column repeats advice she offered in column 10 years ago that any suspicious area in breast should be biopsied even when mammogram is negative; says early discovery of cancer cells in her breast is living proof of value of that advice (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fortis, one of the biggest insurance and banking companies in Europe, said yesterday that it would buy American Bankers Insurance Group, a Miami insurer that was the object of a bidding war by two big American companies last year, for $2.6 billion plus the assumption of nearly $200 million in debt. Fortis plans to combine American Bankers with its American Security Group in Atlanta, giving the new entity an overwhelmingly dominant market share of 30 percent in the business of selling insurance that pays off credit card balances and loans on such things as furniture and major appliances when customers die, lose their jobs or are disabled.

headline.main: Fortis to Buy U.S. Company For $2.6 Billion Plus Debt

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Should patients be able to sue their health maintenance organizations? ALISHA BERGER If somebody is hurt as a result of the improper decisions of an H.M.O., he should be able to sue that H.M.O. and be compensated for the damage. The purpose of the right to sue is to serve as a deterrent against conduct by an H.M.O. that is in reckless disregard of a patient's needs. The Erisa (Employee Retirement Income Security Act) statute, enacted in the 1970's, keeps states from establishing causes of action and keeps patients from suing in state courts. But the statute also says a person can sue in Federal court. If the patient prevails, though, he can get only the service that was originally denied or its dollar value.

headline.main: In Search of Fairness in Patient Care

docs.abstract: Pro & Con: question of whether patients should be able to sue their health maintenance organizations is answered in affirmative by Ron Pollack of Families USA Foundation, and in negative by Richard I Smith of American Assn of Health Plans (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Some doctors and hospitals have been forcing poor women to pay hundreds of dollars in cash for a popular procedure to relieve pain in childbirth, Federal officials say, and the Government has ordered hospitals to stop demanding such cash payments. Federal law says pregnant Medicaid patients may not be charged for prenatal care, delivery or other medical services that relate to pregnancy. Medicaid reimburses hospitals and doctors for such services, but doctors say the payments for pain treatment are grossly inadequate, sometimes only 10 percent or 20 percent of what private insurance companies pay.

headline.main: Mothers on Medicaid Overcharged for Pain Relief

docs.abstract: Medicaid director Sally K Richardson orders doctors and hospitals to stop improperly demanding cash payments from poor women covered by Medicaid for covered services, especially use of epidural block to relieve pain in childbirth, letter to state health officials; doctors say Medicaid payments for epidural are grossly inadequate; photo (M)
